Gonality of modular curves

Feb 23, 2019

This semester, I’m working on a project under Drew Sutherland and Maarten Derickx that hopes to extend Mazur’s classification of torsion subgroups of elliptic curves. Fix a number field , and let be an elliptic curve over . The Mordell-Weil theorem states that is a finitely generated abelian group, and it is classical that the torsion subgroup is generated by two elements; therefore, the torsion subgroup is isomorphic to for some pair of integers . It is known by work of Merel that for a fixed degree , there is only a finite set of possibilites of pairs of torsion points of elliptic curves over number fields of degree .

Mazur’s groundbreaking result computes all possibilities of and when : he shows that

Computing for general values of is harder, so one can instead attempt to solve the weaker problem of computing the subset of torsion subgroups which arise for infinitely many -isomorphism classes of elliptic curves over number fields of degree . Derickx and Sutherland provided a method of computing , which we now recall.

The (rational model for the) modular curve naturally lives (via the Weil pairing) over , and one can prove that the pair lives in if the function field contains a point of degree . The converse is true if the Jacobian is of rank zero (i.e., is entirely torsion). Suppose that we want to prove that is equal to a set of pairs . Then the above discussion suggests that one should first prove that for each , the field contains a point of degree . Then, define a set , where is the Abramovich-Kim-Sarnak bound. If the Jacobian is of rank zero for all , the above discussion implies that has a point of degree if and only if . Let , so that by general theory. Then, to show that , it suffices to prove that for each , the field has no functions of degree .

For , all steps except for the final one have been completed by Derickx-Sutherland. The hardest part is showing that the field has no functions of degree . For this, one relies on the general observation that since has rank for all , we have , where:

  • is the least integer for which the set has infinitely many elements; and
  • is the gonality of , defined as the minimal degree of a finite morphism ; equivalently (at least if is smooth), this is the minimal degree of a line bundle on generated by at least two global sections. If is a curve over with minimal regular model which has good reduction at , then . This is essentially because the map is surjective, so you can choose a lift of a minimal “gonal” line bundle over to , and then specialize to the special fiber.

To prove that has no functions of degree , it therefore suffices to show that . The curve has good reduction at all primes not dividing , so if is such a prime, then . It therefore suffices to prove that there is a prime such that .

Computing this gonality is the primary bottleneck: Derickx and Sutherland used a brute-force algorithm to compute for by running over Riemann-Roch spaces, which we will now briefly describe. Let be a curve over a field ; then, there is a nonconstant function of degree if and only if there is a(n effective Cartier) divisor on of degree such that contains a non-constant function, i.e., if and only if . Therefore, if , then if and only if for all , the Riemann-Roch space has dimension for all . The algorithm, therefore, just runs over all (which is finite if is a finite field) and checks if ; once this is false, we would have found . There is a clear problem with this algorithm when applied to a curve over a finite field : it is too slow if or the gonality of is large.

In fact, I think that this problem is algorithmically hard! Here is a heuristic argument, based on the following approach suggested by Maarten. Let be a divisor on of degree which dominates all divisors of degree , i.e., for all divisors of degree , we have . Then, there is a map ; let denote the subspace of given by the image of this map. Write , so that , where is the degree of the field of definition of . This defines a generalized Hamming weight as follows: for , let , where for a fixed , is the largest for which . It is then the case that for if and only if the minimum distance is . The problem of computing gonalities therefore reduces to the problem of computing the minimum distance of a linear subspace of with respect to the generalized Hamming weight given by a partition of as .

Getting back to number theory, another observation is that the algorithm above doesn’t really use the fact that the curve under consideration is very special; let’s try to specialize to the cases where we need to compute the gonality. The first case not addressed by Derickx and Sutherland’s paper is , and at the end of their introduction, they say that the outstanding problem in computing is showing that for . In these cases, it is pretty hard to use the algorithm above to prove such a lower bound on the gonality of (which, I imagine, is why it isn’t done in the paper). One needs something a bit better.

Instead of considering the curve , let us consider the curve for odd . Let be the associated moduli stack over , so that is a proper flat regular Artin stack (see Theorem 1.2.1 here). Then by Theorem 13.7.6 of Katz-Mazur (one of my favorite books of all time), the fiber of the Artin stack is a gluing of two copies of — the extension of scalars of by Frobenius — at the supersingular points. (Think in analogy to the famous picture of as being two copies of glued at the supersingular point.) This is good, because we know the gonality of , at least for small . However, it is not so clear how one might compare the gonality of a curve (in our case, ) and the gonality of a minimal regular model of it over a prime of bad reduction. In any case, I proposed this idea to Maarten, and he pointed me to a masters thesis which implements exactly this idea. I haven’t had a chance to read the paper in detail, but it seems like the fact that the curve is smooth (which is true because was assumed to be odd) is key. This is no longer true for the fiber over of the curve for even . I don’t know if this fiber has been studied (I don’t know how to google this sort of thing), but as far as I know, it isn’t covered in Katz-Mazur, at least. Nonetheless, it might be possible to modify the portions of the proof in Chapter 13 of their book to obtain some partial results that’d be sufficient to use techniques similar to the thesis linked to above in order to obtain lower bounds on .
